Title: Beth Shalom Temple (Havana, Cuba)
Content:
Hebrew community centre in Havana. Conservative.

KWB's Highlights:
  • Temple Beth Shalom, built in 1952, is a synagogue located in the Vedado neighborhood of downtown Havana.
  • If you have more information we would be happy to update this page.
  • To understand why there is no official Chabad in Cuba, which is also related to this organization, check out this article.
  • There are two synagogues in town (a Sephardic one nearby and the Orthodox in the old town), this is the main community building and the largest congregation.
  • In 1981, much of the original building was sold to the state and was then turned into the Bertolt Brecht Cultural Center, including a theatre, a music venue, a gallery, and a bar.
  • Overall, the Jewish community in Cuba has enjoyed security and anti-Semitism has been minimal. In the years leading up to his death, Fidel Castro even attended the community's Hanukka celebration. (source)

Title: Jewish Community of Birobidjan

  • The first-ever public mikvah is currently under construction in this famous Yiddish-speaking city of Birobidzhan.

Title: Jewish Community of Astrakhan
Content:
Chabad centre in Astrakhan, Russia.

KWB's Highlights:
  • Astrakhan is a city in southern Russia and the administrative centre of Astrakhan Oblast. The city lies on two banks of the Volga River, close to where it opens into the Caspian Sea at an altitude of 28 metres below sea level.
  • The revival of Jewish community and religious life in Astrakhan began in the 1990s. Just months after the opening of the reconstructed synagogue in April 2003, the community welcomed Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Goldenberg, the first rabbi to serve the city in seventy years.
  • Rabbi Goldenberg works closely with Yuri Feldman, the Chairman of Astrakhan’s Jewish community, on all questions concerning the community’s development.
  • Local Jews play an active part in the community through involvement in the Family Club, Women’s Club, and the ‘Golden Age’ Club. These clubs’ activities are generally of a fun yet educational nature, including lectures, interactive presentations and group discussions on Jewish traditions and holidays, as well as festive meals.
  • The Jewish community operates a Jewish Youth Club, which offers teenagers and youth the opportunity to learn more about Jewish culture and traditions, gain a contemporary outlook on Jewish tradition, become more aware of their Jewish self-identity and learn about what it means to be a Jew today.
  • Club members also regularly participate in all community celebrations, usually putting on skits and other performances.

  • Since January 2004, a Sunday school, a women's club, has started operating.

  • Daily prayers are held in the minyan, each week members of the community gather in the synagogue to meet Shabbat together.
  • The community organises and conducts large Jewish holidays. For two years the newspaper of the Jewish community "Revival" was published.

More details:
  • The capital city of New Delhi is considered the most convenient starting point for backpackers in India. The first stop in town is the central market – the “Main Bazaar”, located in the midst of old narrow streets in a crowded, noisy and filthy area.
  • In the heart of the market, in a modest and pleasant building, ever since 5755 (1995) sits the oldest Chabad House in India.
  • The Chabad House has been run in recent years with admirable devotion by Rabbi Shmulik and Mira Sharf.
  • Under extremely hard conditions they welcome hundreds of new backpackers who have just set foot on Indian soil every day, and they do so warmly and with a smile.
  • The backpackers who have a hard time getting used to the crowded city, find a quiet Jewish home in the Chabad House. Thus the Chabad House in New Delhi functions as a gateway to all the other Chabad Houses in India.
  • The Chabad House provides the visitors and the hotels in town with Kosher food. It has an information centre for the backpackers on all the relevant issues and it also supports Jewish inmates in Indian prisons.
  • As a Chabad House located in the capital city, it coordinates all the assistance in urgent medical cases, the procedures involved when Jews pass away in India and the rescue of backpackers in hard mental states, as well as those captured by pagan sects. The Chabad House in New Delhi also serves as the link between all the Chabad Houses in India in order to promote joint goals.
Travel Tips:
  • Many travellers get caught up in the chaos of the city, a short drive from the airport to the Main Bazaar may develop unpleasant experiences and result in significant expenses, so keep that in mind.

Jewish Center of Iceland

Chabad Jewish Center of Iceland is a home where everyone is welcome - regardless of affiliation, level of knowledge or observance.

They strive to create a warm, welcoming environment to explore and experience our heritage in a non-judgmental and inviting atmosphere.

This Chabad was founded on the principle that, while Jews may embrace many levels of observance in their personal lives, there should be a place for all Jews - no labels and no affiliations - to develop a sense of community, to enhance the experience of being Jewish, to learn, and enjoy Judaism.

Their mission:

To strengthen the Iceland community by promoting Jewish pride, education and celebration.

To provide for the spiritual & material needs of all Jews in the community - regardless of their background, affiliation or financial means, and to provide insight and explanation on Judaism’s history and universal values to our friends beyond the Jewish community who would like to learn more.

To establish a warm and traditional community centre where everyone is made to feel welcome and comfortable.

They have a hashgacha by Rabbi Rozmarin.

Title: Chabad Lubavitch Cannes
Content:
Friendly and welcoming Chabad House.

KWB's Highlights:
  • The worldwide Chabad Lubavitch movement opened its centre in Cannes in 1989.
  • Famous for its International Film Festival, Cannes is located in the southern part of France, the French Riviera.
  • Cannes is an elegant city known around the world and attracts an international clientele.
  • Many organisations are included under Chabad of Cannes:
    • The Synagogue of Rue Commandant Vidal.
    • The day School L’Ecole Juive de Cannes.
    • The social organisation “Centre d’Accueil et d’Animation Cannois”.
    • The Judaica shop Cann’or.
    • The “Jewish Tourist Center of the French Riviera”, including many “summer Synagogues”.
    • The JJC – Jewish youth organisation.
    • The Jewish Learning Centre “Tiferet Shlomo”.
    • The Jewish Community of St Tropez.
    • The Jewish Community of Mandelieu-la-Napoule.
    • The Jewish Community of Le Cannet-Mougins (NEW).
  • In addition to servicing the local Jews, with many programmes geared for young people, it has become an international centre which greets visitors from aboard with great warmth and friendliness.
  • All these efforts are directed by Rabbi Yehuda Leib Matusof and his son Rabbi Mendel Matusof.
  • Located a minute away from the famous “Croisette”, don’t forget to visit Chabad, on vacation or on a business trip. (source)
About the synagogue
  • The Chabad House - Shul is located 22 Rue Commandant Vidal, corner Boulevard de Lorraine. It is a minute away from the "Croisette" boardwalk.
  • Walking directions: On the Croisette, at the Palais Stephanie (ex Noga Hilton), take rue Amouretti, the street becomes rue Signoret (go past rue d’Antibes), which becomes rue Commandant Vidal. In the end, they are on your right.
Service times
  • Daily: 8:30 AM and Mincha according to the season.
  • Friday night: Entrance of Shabbat. Shabbat morning: 9:30 AM. Mincha: same as Friday night.
 Accommodation
  • Cannes has more than 100 hotels. You can find them on cannes.com or by calling the tourist office: + 33 (0)4 93 99 19 77 or +33 (0)4 92 99 84 22.
  • The Chabad is located in the middle of the centre of Cannes.
  • The closest 5 star hotels to Chabad are the “J.W. Mariott - Palais Stéphanie” www.jwmariottcannes.com tel +33 (0)4 92 99 70 00, and the Carlton Intercontinental www.ichotelsgroup.com tel +33 (0)4 93 06 40 06.
  • If you need any more information, please do not hesitate to contact us Rabbi Mendel Matusof or Rabbi Yudi Levin: info@habadcannes.com - by phone: +33 (0)4 92 98 67 51.
Shabbat
  • Pre-order at Restaurant Le Tovel, 3 Rue Gérard Monod, Tel: +33 (0)4 93 39 36 25.
  • Email: gillesfadloun@hotmail.fr (may be open to eat there or to take away, depending on the number of reservations that week).
